Situation1: They notice a mentee struggling with time management during casual check-ins.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I sat on the poolside bench, clipboard in hand, listening as my mentee, Jamie, described her chaotic week. She was overwhelmed, missing deadlines, and I could see the frustration in her eyes. As her mentor, I wanted to guide her, help her break down her schedule, and encourage her to find balance. I was about to offer advice when, out of the corner of my eye, I spotted a group of teenagers laughing and edging dangerously close to the deep end, blatantly ignoring the no-diving signs. My lifeguard instincts kicked in—safety was non-negotiable, and I was responsible for every person in that pool. But Jamie needed me, too; she was finally opening up, trusting me to help her grow. My mind raced, torn between the urge to enforce the rules and the desire to be present for Jamie. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, and I felt the tension coil in my chest as I hesitated, caught between two worlds.
